ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Through the course, we were able to better understand how research works within the context of Africa.
I learned to thing critically about specific solutions to different governance issues in Africa. I learned to pitch different policy proposals to solve governance issues in Africa.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: I know that Professor Lierl is relatively new to academia, but this course was a clusterf--- (can I say that in evaluations?). I came into this course thinking it would be about governance in Africa, given the course title "Governance in Africa". However, the coursework was just reading research studies conducted by others. There was no knowledge base of how governance in Africa actually works on either the national or local levels, and the entire class was merely reading research papers about fixing problems associated with African governance. Class discussions were another issue. Professor Lierl would pose a question to the class and, since no one ever did the readings because they were dull and time-consuming, we would just sit in silence for minutes at a time, staring at each other. There wasn't much helpful feedback on the course projects, many of which were written about countries outside of Africa.
I would have liked more feedback on assignments throughout the semester. I really like the syllabus, it was well structured and organized.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Definitely take it if you are interested in the area. Not a great introduction to development itself, but a good followup course.
